author: By Emily Flitter
title: Wells Fargo Revives Policy That Led to Fake Job Interviews, With Tweaks
description: The bank will reinstate a requirement to assemble a “diverse slate” of job candidates while adding flexibility, according to an internal memo.
content: Wells Fargo is reactivating a hiring practice that it paused this year after a former employee revealed that it was leading managers to interview nonwhite candidates for jobs that had already been filled, according to a memo seen by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Putnam and Micah L. Sifry
title: Fed Up With Democratic Emails? You’re Not the Only One.
description: Hammering voters with breathless emails and apocalyptic messages is preventing  Democrats from building a lasting political movement.
content: Donald Trump seemed to usher in a new era of Democratic grass-roots engagement. More than four million people marched in the streets the day after his inauguration. Several thousand chapters of Indivisible, one of the biggest new “Resistance” organizations, sprung up, covering every congressional district. On the Democratic fund-raising platform ActBlue, the number of donors more than quadrupled in roughly four years, reaching 15 million during the 2020 election cycle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Tropical Ice Creams With Bold and Subtle Flavors
description: Frutero, a frozen dessert company from Philadelphia, produces uncommon flavors like tangerine.
content: Frutero makes the sorts of flavors more often found in sorbet than ice cream. But the intensity of the tangy-sweet tropical harvest shines through in Frutero’s creamy tangerine, passion fruit and pineapple, to name a few. These and the coconut are the most vibrant varieties in the collection from this two-year-old Philadelphia company. Guava, guanabana and mango are more delicate. The ice creams were all inspired by confections that Vedant Saboo, a founder of the company, had been familiar with from his childhood in India.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Caro
title: Rebounding From a Revolt, Victory Gardens Is Again Mired in Turmoil
description: The esteemed Chicago theater’s artistic director is out, and artists and his supporters are upset with the company’s board of directors.
content: CHICAGO — Victory Gardens Theater, a vibrant fixture here since 1974, had long prided itself on being a champion of diversity while also bringing new works to its audiences. In 2001, it received the Tony Award for outstanding regional theater for its role in “contributing to the growth of theater nationally.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: How Some Parents Changed Their Politics in the Pandemic
description: They were once Democrats and Republicans. But fears for their children in the pandemic transformed their thinking, turning them into single-issue voters for November’s midterms.
content: ORINDA, Calif. — They waved signs that read “Defeat the mandates” and “No vaccines.” They chanted “Protect our kids” and “Our kids, our choice.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neelam Bohra
title: ‘They’re Just Going to Let Me Die?’ One Woman’s Abortion Odyssey
description: Madison Underwood was thrilled to learn she was pregnant. But when a rare defect in the developing fetus threatened her life, she was thrust into post-Roe chaos.
content: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — Madison Underwood was lying on the ultrasound table, nearly 19 weeks pregnant, when the doctor came in to say her abortion had been canceled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: A Journalist Was Told Her Skirt Was Too Short to Report on an Execution
description: Ivana Hrynkiw Shatara, a reporter for AL.com, was one of two female reporters covering the execution at an Alabama prison last week who were questioned over their clothing.
content: When a prison official in Alabama told a reporter covering an execution last week that her skirt was too short, she pulled it down to her hips to make it longer. When that didn’t suffice, she borrowed a pair of fishing waders from a photographer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker, Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Drone Strike Kills Ayman al-Zawahri, Top Qaeda Leader
description: The strike, carried out over the weekend, was the first attack since American forces left Afghanistan last year.
content: WASHINGTON — An American drone strike killed Ayman al-Zawahri, a key plotter of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks who took over as the leader of Al Qaeda after Osama bin Laden’s death, at an urban safe house in Afghanistan, President Biden announced on Monday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: In Israel, a Biblical Tongue Meets Gender Politics
description: A linguistic revolution is underway in the quest for more gender-inclusive language for Hebrew, whose modern form adopted grammatical norms from 3,000 years ago. Not everybody is on board.
content: JERUSALEM — Hebrew, with its roots in a biblical patriarchy, and reinvented 3,000 years later to become the lingua franca of today’s Israel, has become the focus of efforts to make it more gender inclusive in the modern age.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The government’s lawsuit to block Penguin Random House buying Simon & Schuster goes to trial.
description: When the largest publisher in the country, Penguin Random House, struck a deal in the fall of 2020 to acquire its rival Simon & Schuster, publishing executives and antitrust experts predicted that the merger would draw intense scrutiny from government regulators, Alexandra Alter, Elizabeth A. Harris and David McCabe report for The New York Times.
content: When the largest publisher in the country, Penguin Random House, struck a deal in the fall of 2020 to acquire its rival Simon & Schuster, publishing executives and antitrust experts predicted that the merger would draw intense scrutiny from government regulators, Alexandra Alter, Elizabeth A. Harris and David McCabe report for The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Trump Pick for Michigan Governor, Tudor Dixon, Dodges Question About 2020
description: The Republican hopeful has called the 2020 election stolen. But she sidestepped questions during an appearance on Fox News just two days after receiving the former president’s endorsement.
content: Two days after receiving former President Donald J. Trump’s endorsement in the Michigan governor’s race, Tudor Dixon would not say whether she still believes that Mr. Trump won the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurtis Lee
title: Why an Iconic California Meatpacking Plant Is Closing
description: Smithfield Foods is shutting its factory in Vernon early next year.
content: When I arrived before dawn at the pork processing plant, I could see lights from the downtown Los Angeles skyline flickering a few miles to the north. It was one of those heavy, gloomy mornings — one with a thick marine layer that so many of us Southern Californians know to expect in the summertime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: In ‘Cyclorama,’ Former Classmates Confront an Extra Problematic Drama Teacher
description: The plot of Adam Langer’s new novel revolves around a high school’s theatrical production of “The Diary of Anne Frank.”
content: As the old saying goes, comedy equals tragedy plus time. Adam Langer’s new novel, “Cyclorama,” significantly complicates that equation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Wine Worthy of a Blind Tasting
description: Prisoner Wine Company’s latest is a blanc de noir.
content: Blanc de noir refers to white wine made from red grapes like pinot noir, engineered so the juice, which is white, is barely or not at all in contact with the red skins. It’s typical for Champagne, but occasionally winemakers pull it off to produce a still white wine, as the Prisoner Wine Company of St. Helena, Calif., has done with its new Blindfold Blanc de Noir. Some viognier and gewürztraminer are also blended in. The unusual result is pale and refreshing, with hints of citrus zest and a whisper of nutty toastiness. Pour it blind, as the name suggests, and ask your wine-loving friends to guess the grape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Beyoncé Will Change Lyrics After Criticism Over ‘Ableist Language’
description: The pop star’s decision to replace two words in her song “Heated” follows Lizzo’s removal of the same term, which has been used as a slur against disabled people, from her track “Grrrls.”
content: Days after the release of her latest album, “Renaissance,” Beyoncé will modify the lyrics of one of its songs, a representative for the singer said on Monday, in response to an outcry from disability rights advocates who say the pop star should not have used a word that has historically been employed as a derogatory slur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: War, Climate Change, Energy Costs: How the Wheat Market Has Been Upended
description: The price has fallen sharply from its peak after one major producer, Russia, invaded another, Ukraine. But that hasn’t ended fears of a global hunger crisis.
content: The price of wheat has tumbled from its peak after Russia invaded Ukraine, but experts say one of the world’s most widely consumed foods remains in short supply and warn that a global hunger crisis still looms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: How the N.Y.P.D. Failed Victims of Sexual Attacks
description: The Special Victims Division is under federal investigation. Women who were attacked said officers often didn’t know how to investigate, or didn’t bother.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. More than 2,000 speed cams go into round-the-clock operation today. But first, we’ll take a closer look at the Police Department’s troubled Special Victims Division — and why rape survivors asked the Justice Department to investigate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amal El-Mohtar
title: How to Fix a Broken World
description: Three new books, from epic fantasy to biological thriller, consider an age-old question.
content: An evergreen question for our times: How do we fix the world?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: First Cargo Ship Passes Russia’s Black Sea Blockade Under Grain Deal
description: For the first time since Russia invaded Ukraine in February, a ship loaded with corn sailed out of Odesa, part of a deal officials hope will help ease food shortages around the world.
content: MYKOLAIV, Ukraine — A ship loaded with corn on Monday became the first cargo vessel to sail from Ukraine in more than five months of war, passing through Russia’s naval blockade of Ukraine’s Black Sea ports and raising hopes that desperately needed food will soon reach nations afflicted by shortages and soaring prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Lai
title: Bipartisan Abortion-Rights Bill Sets Up a Midterm Debate
description: Four senators, two Democrats and two Republicans, joined forces to introduce legislation to guarantee abortion access after Roe v. Wade was overturned. But the bill has little chance of advancing.
content: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group of senators released a bill on Monday that would create a federal baseline for abortion access, the first bipartisan legislative effort on the issue since the Supreme Court struck down the Roe v. Wade ruling that established abortion rights nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By April Rubin
title: After Days of Punishing Heat, the Pacific Northwest Is Expected to Cool
description: Sunday was the seventh consecutive day in Portland, Ore., in which temperatures reached 95 degrees or higher, breaking the previous record of six days in a row.
content: After getting pummeled by multiple consecutive days of 90 degrees or higher that had climbed into the triple digits in some cities, the Pacific Northwest is expected to gain some relief this week before temperatures rise again this weekend, forecasters said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky urges mass evacuations.
content: Volodymyr Zelensky, the Ukrainian president, urged civilians in the eastern Donbas region to evacuate. The more people leave the Donetsk region now, he said, “the fewer people the Russian Army will have time to kill.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Miller
title: Liz Cheney Is Prepared to Lose Power, and It Shows
description: The meaning, and cost, of going against Donald Trump.
content: WASHINGTON — What should you do when you know you’re losing?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Bill Russell Paved the Way for Black Coaches to Defy Doubters
description: When getting hired as a Black coach seemed “far-fetched,” as one coach said, Russell showed that it could be done — and that it could lead to championships.
content: Bill Russell and Red Auerbach came to an agreement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Farber
title: Mo Ostin, Music Powerhouse Who Put Artists First, Dies at 95
description: At the helm of Warner Bros. Records from the 1960s into the ’90s, he worked closely with some of the most successful and influential performers of his era.
content: Mo Ostin, who in his many years as the powerful chief executive of Warner Bros. Records made a point of putting the artist first, in the process encouraging the most important works of musicians like Jimi Hendrix, Neil Young and Prince, died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Bill Russell’s Legacy, and Laugh, Touched Millions
description: Russell showed as much love and respect to younger players as they showed to him. Some, like Charles Barkley, referred to him simply as “Mr. Russell.”
content: It was a day to celebrate Elgin Baylor, whom the Los Angeles Lakers had just honored with a statue outside their home arena. On that warm evening in April 2018, one of Baylor’s greatest antagonists showed up and sat prominently in the crowd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Older Generations Are Reclaiming Rites of Passage
description: Rituals like graduations and weddings are few and far between for older adults. Some are finding ways to honor their momentous occasions.
content: Harry Oxman’s bar mitzvah at the Society Hill Synagogue in Philadelphia looked much like the traditional Saturday morning event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Moving in With Mom: Redistricting Creates Upheaval for N.Y. Lawmakers
description: New district maps for the New York State Senate have caused some incumbents to run in neighboring districts and to contemplate new living arrangements.
content: Earlier this year, New York’s tumultuous redistricting process convulsed the state’s House races, sparking intraparty drama that has provoked free-for-all primary contests and forced high-ranking Democrats to run against each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Wembi and Abdi Latif Dahir
title: U.N. Peacekeepers Kill 2 and Wound 15 in Congo
description: The events on Sunday came amid protests in eastern Congo, with demonstrators accusing the United Nations of foundering in its efforts to protect civilians from a surge in violence.
content: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — United Nations peacekeepers opened fire at a border crossing in the Democratic Republic of Congo on Sunday, U.N. and Congolese authorities said, killing two people and injuring 15 others in a spasm of violence that punctuated weeks of tensions over the agency’s role in Africa’s second-largest nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: The Abortion Decision, Haunted by Brown v. Board of Education
description: The justices cited the landmark 1954 decision banning segregation in public schools 23 times, debating its meaning and methods.
content: WASHINGTON — In the Supreme Court decision that eliminated the constitutional right to abortion, the justices engaged in an extended debate over the meaning and legacy of Brown v. Board of Education, the 1954 decision that said the Constitution does not permit racial segregation in public schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Lai
title: G.O.P. Reversal Imperils Bill to Treat Veteran Ailments From Toxic Exposure
description: Several Republicans who had backed the measure blocked it last week, drawing ire from Democrats and veterans groups who expected quick enactment. Another vote is planned for this week.
content: WASHINGTON — A broadly supported bill to expand medical care eligibility for millions of veterans who may have been exposed to toxins from burning pits of trash on U.S. military bases has become ensnared in a partisan fight over spending, leaving its fate uncertain after a large group of Republicans pulled their support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriel Popkin
title: This Pushy Plant Is the First Proved to Shove Its Neighbor
description: The behavior could help study a longstanding mystery of how so many plants share small amounts of space.
content: Life as a short plant can be tough. Taller competitors hog the sunlight, leaving shrimpier species to photosynthesize from whatever scraps filter through. But at least one ground-hugger has found a solution that many of us more diminutive humans have probably at least fantasized about: shoving those rangy neighbors out of the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: ‘Team Molly’ Parents Sue E-Bike Company Over Daughter’s Death
description: An online community offered support for Molly Steinsapir, a 12-year-old who experienced brain trauma in an accident last year. Her mother and father have filed suit against Rad Power Bikes.
content: The parents of a girl who died after an e-bike accident filed a wrongful-death lawsuit on Monday against the Seattle e-bike company Rad Power Bikes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: CMA Fest and ‘Becoming Elizabeth’
description: ABC airs footage from the 2022 CMA Fest. And a period drama on Starz wraps up its first season.
content: With network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Aug. 1-7. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Why Pelosi’s Visit to Taiwan Is Utterly Reckless
description: The timing could not be worse. The Ukraine war is not over.
content: I have a lot of respect for House Speaker Nancy Pelosi. But if she does go ahead with a visit to Taiwan this week, against President Biden’s wishes, she will be doing something that is utterly reckless, dangerous and irresponsible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Why It’s So Hard to Find an Affordable Apartment in New York
description: There simply aren’t enough places to live, a crisis decades in the making and one that poses a threat to the city’s continuing recovery.
content: A half a century ago, city planners warned that New York had the potential to swell into a “monster city” of 55 million people. To avoid this fate, the city passed a major overhaul of zoning rules in 1961, limiting the size of buildings and how many people could live in them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Pixar’s Ousted Founder Returns With Apple and ‘Luck’
description: John Lasseter was toppled five years ago by allegations about his workplace behavior. He’s back with an animated film and a studio that could be Pixar 2.0.
content: LOS ANGELES — The most Pixar movie of the summer is not from Pixar. It’s from Apple TV+ and the lightning-rod filmmaker-executive who turned Pixar into a superpower: John Lasseter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: What Remote Work Debate? They’ve Been Back at the Office for a While.
description: Cubicles are largely empty in downtown San Francisco and Midtown Manhattan, but workers in America’s midsize and small cities are back to their commutes.
content: The competition for parking space is getting steeper. Commutes are inching longer. Workplace lounges are filling up with commotion as junior associates play cornhole. What return-to-office debate? In some parts of the country, it’s been settled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winston Choi-Schagrin and Elena Shao
title: Why Does the American West Have So Many Wildfires?
description: Four main reasons that California and other Western states are particularly prone to deadly blazes, which are intensifying as the world warms.
content: In just one weekend, the McKinney Fire, fueled by strong winds and high temperatures, burned more than 55,000 acres in Northern California, becoming the state’s largest wildfire so far this year. The blaze is only the beginning of the West’s fire season, which traditionally peaks between mid-July and October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kalia Richardson
title: Netflix Sues ‘Unofficial Bridgerton Musical’ Duo for Infringement
description: Abigail Barlow and Emily Bear gained prominence through TikTok and won a Grammy Award for their musical take on the hit streaming series.
content: Netflix has sued the team behind “The Unofficial Bridgerton Musical,” claiming that the Grammy-winning lyricist-composer duo infringed on the hit show’s intellectual property, according to a complaint filed in the U.S. District Court in Washington, D.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Pelosi Backs Rep. Mondaire Jones in Crowded Open-Seat Race in New York
description: The first-term congressman, who moved to Brooklyn to compete in the redrawn 10th Congressional District, faces a highly competitive race.
content: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Monday endorsed Representative Mondaire Jones, a first-term upstate congressman who is facing a stiff battle in his bid to capture an open seat in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Seymour
title: The Fantasy of Brexit Britain Is Over
description: The country is being cut down to size.
content: LONDON — The Boris Johnson era is over. But the turmoil has only just begun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: The Trading Deadline Is Where Good Teams Get Great
description: The Yankees already had the best record in the American League, but trades for Frankie Montas, Andrew Benintendi and two relievers prove they know what they need.
content: The best teams need to do the most work at the baseball trading deadline. This would seem counterintuitive, because the best teams tend to have the fewest needs. But if a team is really good, the hardest part is over: you know you’ll be playing in October. Trades are all about boosting your odds once you get there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas and Ken Belson
title: Deshaun Watson Suspended Six N.F.L. Games for Sexual Misconduct
description: The former Houston Texans quarterback who recently signed a $230 million guaranteed contract with the Cleveland Browns will not be fined. A lawyer for Watson’s accusers called the discipline “a slap in the face.”
content: Deshaun Watson, the Cleveland Browns quarterback accused by more than two dozen women of sexual misconduct during massage treatments, was suspended Monday for six games without pay for multiple violations of the National Football League’s personal conduct policy, according to a 16-page report released by the disciplinary officer who considered his case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Simonetti
title: Home buying firm settles deceptive marketing claims for $62 million.
description: The Federal Trade Commission accused Opendoor of deceiving customers into offering their properties to the online platform for less than they would have made on the open market.
content: Opendoor Labs, an online home buying platform, agreed on Monday to pay $62 million to the Federal Trade Commission to settle claims that it used misleading marketing practices to persuade people to sell their homes on the site.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Democrats’ Climate Deal Isn’t Done Yet. Here Are the Remaining Hurdles.
description: An agreement with Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia salvaged a key piece of President Biden’s agenda. But Democrats still have a few crucial steps to take before it becomes law.
content: WASHINGTON — When Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, a key centrist holdout, announced a surprise deal last week with Chuck Schumer of New York, the majority leader, on a climate, energy and tax package, Democrats exulted that a significant piece of their domestic policy agenda had been saved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Maria Varenikova
title: Here’s what we know about the deadly blast at a prisoner camp in eastern Ukraine.
description: An explosion at a detention camp killed at least 50 Ukrainian prisoners of war, in what Ukrainians are calling a war crime.
content: A blast at a detention camp in eastern Ukraine killed at least 50 Ukrainian prisoners of war. The attack has enraged Ukrainians, who call it a war crime. Russia said, without offering evidence, that a Ukrainian missile strike caused the explosion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Campbell Robertson
title: In Kentucky, More Rain Complicates Recovery as Death Toll Rises
description: Days after floods ravaged the eastern part of the state, the governor said that hundreds of people remained unaccounted for.
content: WHITESBURG, Ky. — One round of rainstorms after another blew through eastern Kentucky on Monday, deepening the misery of an already desperate region. Floodwaters again swallowed the roads that had recently reopened to allow emergency workers to scour the remote hills and valleys for survivors; creeks once again swelled into the streets of small towns where people had just begun the gloomy work of emptying houses of their waterlogged contents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Maybe Joe Biden Knows Joe Manchin Better Than We Thought
description: There is at least one person in politics who was not taken by surprise by the new climate and tax package.
content: Gail Collins: Never really thought I’d be leading off with a toast to Joe Manchin, Bret, but troubled times require low expectations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: I Gave Up on High Heels. What Can I Wear Instead?
description: A reader is looking for comfortable and stylish flats to wear to a formal occasion.
content: Yoko Ono married John Lennon in flats. Keira Knightley married her husband, the musician James Righton, in flats. Jerry Hall married Rupert Murdoch in flats. OK, maybe that last example was not the best, given they are now splitting up, but the point is: If these women, very much in the public eye, can wear flats to what is one of the most important dressing-up moments of their lives, the rest of us can also wear them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: The Remarkable ‘Reservation Dogs’ Runs Away Toward Home
description: The second season of this Native coming-of-age comedy deepens its emotion and builds on its sense of place.
content: Wanting to escape your hometown is the birthright of every young person. In America, pulling up stakes and hitting the road is built into the popular culture — it’s “Go west, young man”; it’s a Bruce Springsteen lyric.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler, Neelam Bohra, McKenna Oxenden and Ginny Whitehouse
title: What We Know About the Victims in the Kentucky Flooding
description: As officials braced for the death toll to climb, family members shared memories of those lost.
content: When the rain came, Diana Amburgey was in her double-wide trailer across from the gas station she managed in Hindman, Ky., packing for a Florida vacation. At 65, she had never learned to swim and was terrified of water, but her family had managed — “for the first time in forever,” her daughter said — to talk her into taking a family trip to the beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Collier Meyerson
title: Dan Smith Might Teach You Guitar
description: Teaching is a calling for New York’s king of the marketing flier, whose students include the former governor David Paterson. But he won’t take just anyone.
content: For three decades, Dan Smith has been making a solemn promise to New Yorkers. He has posted his flier — “Dan Smith Will Teach You Guitar” — thousands of times in the city’s bodegas, coffee shops, pizza parlors, delis and laundromats. Parodied by Jon Stewart and the guitar god John Mayer, Mr. Smith has reached local legend status alongside the likes of Cellino & Barnes, Dr. Zizmor and Keano.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Grain Shipments Start Moving
description: A first ship left Ukraine’s ports and 16 more are ready to bring grain to world markets.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: ‘Friending Bias’
description: A large new study offers clues about how lower-income children can rise up the economic ladder.
content: Social scientists have made it a priority in recent years to understand upward mobility. They have used tax records and other data to study which factors increase the chances that children who grow up in poverty will be able to escape it as adults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: From Pizza to Dip, Chips and Popcorn, Pickle Is Summer’s Big Flavor
description: For people with a sweet-and-sour tooth, there’s never been a greater pick of pickle-flavored possibilities, thanks to pickle spice.
content: In May, Meg and Maddie Antonelli, a mother-and-daughter duo who review new food products on TikTok, filmed themselves in their car in a Florida grocery store parking lot. Meg held up a container of powdered dill pickle seasoning from Sam’s Club; Maddie, a bag of Goldfish Original crackers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Supply-Side Economics Isn’t Just for Republicans Anymore
description: Democrats are shaping their own version.
content: Today’s intolerably high inflation is a result of too much money chasing too few goods. The harsh way to lower inflation is to deal with the “too much money” side of the equation by raising interest rates or taxes, which chokes off the public’s spending power. The infinitely better way to combat inflation, when possible, is to deal with the “too few goods” side by increasing the supply of things to buy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Using Nuclear Reactors for Cover, Russians Lob Rockets at Ukrainians
description: Russia has turned Europe’s largest nuclear power plant into a fortress, stymying Ukraine’s forces and unnerving locals who fear both shelling and a radiation leak.
content: NIKOPOL, Ukraine — Along most of the front line in Russia’s war in Ukraine, when one side lets loose with an artillery attack, the other shoots back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: His Campaign Pitch? ‘No One Wants to Have a Beer With Me.’
description: Adam Hollier, a Democratic House candidate in Michigan, has a self-effacing message for voters that reflects his life story.
content: By his own admission, Adam Hollier is not the kind of guy you want to have a beer with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Prison Officials Remove Ban on Attica Book, Except for 2 Crucial Pages
description: In response to the author’s First Amendment lawsuit, officials said the alteration was necessary for “security reasons.”
content: New York officials are cutting and inserting pages in a book about the state’s most notorious prison in an attempt to resolve a festering First Amendment dispute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Manchin Won a Pledge From Democrats to Finish a Contested Pipeline
description: To cement the senator’s support for a climate and tax package, party leaders promised to pass a law to complete the line and to prioritize some other fossil fuel projects.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia has secured a promise from Democratic leaders and the White House to complete a highly contested 304-mile gas pipeline in his state, his office said, a major concession won as part of negotiations over a climate and tax bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Stream These 10 Titles Before They Leave Netflix in August
description: Of the many movies leaving the streaming service for U.S. subscribers this month, these are the ones most worth checking out.
content: There are scares aplenty in the titles leaving Netflix in the United States at the end of the month, with two contemporary horror favorites and one absolute classic departing the service. We can also recommend a handful of first-rate thrillers, one of the most quotable comedies of the 21st century and a Kevin Costner Western that’s neither “Dances With Wolves” or “Yellowstone.” (Dates reflect the final day a title is available.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivien Schweitzer
title: Mick Moloney, Musician and Champion of Irish Culture, Dies at 77
description: An Irish immigrant to the U.S., he was a recording artist, scholar and concert presenter who also encouraged women to join a male-dominated folk tradition.
content: Mick Moloney, a recording artist, folklorist, concert presenter and professor who championed traditional Irish culture and encouraged female instrumentalists in a male-dominated field, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan, in Greenwich Village. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rachelle Bonja, Michael Simon Johnson, Sydney Harper, M.J. Davis Lin, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: How Monkeypox Went From Containable to Crisis
description: The United States, despite having time and tools at its disposal, has failed to bring the virus to heel.
content: In mid-June, cases of monkeypox were in the double digits in the United States. There were drug treatments and vaccines against it. There didn’t seem to be any reason for alarm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: Gabino Iglesias, a Writer of Noir, Explores the Texas Underworld
description: Iglesias arrived in Austin with $236 to his name. After being told his name had “too many vowels” for him to find success, he’s on the cusp of noir stardom.
content: AUSTIN, Tex. — At the dawn of the pandemic, Gabino Iglesias had already been living paycheck to paycheck in Texas for more than a decade. Then the public high school where he was teaching had devastating news: He was being let go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Coffee From Yemen, With a Literary Connection
description: A nonprofit from Mokhtar Alkhanshali, the central figure in Dave Egger’s book “The Monk of Mokha,” is helping roasters connect with Yemeni farmers.
content: In 2018 Dave Eggers wrote the improbable nail-biter, “The Monk of Mokha,” about Mokhtar Alkhanshali — an American citizen of Yemeni parents barely scraping by in San Francisco — who went to Yemen to reestablish the coffee trade in his ancestral country, the place said to be where coffee-drinking originated. He went often to Yemen, escaped the raging civil war and founded a company, Port of Mokha, to sell coffee. Last week, while tasting several coffees from Yemen Mr. Alkhanshali said he also wanted to create a nonprofit organization to help coffee farmers, 75 percent of whom are women; the result is the Mokha Institute. This year for the first time, it will run the National Yemen Coffee Auction open to roasters worldwide. The institute has selected 28 coffees, out of an original collection of 161, for the online auction; registration is open until Aug. 15 and the auction will be held Aug. 31. He said that roasters from 20 countries are expected to participate. Much of Yemen’s coffee, all arabica, is grown on steep terraced land in the mountainous western part of the country and is sun-dried, not washed. “We don’t have much water,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: The G.O.P. nominee for Maryland attorney general promoted 9/11 conspiracy theories.
description: Resurfaced comments that Michael Anthony Peroutka made drew condemnation from the state’s departing Republican governor, Larry Hogan.
content: The Republican governor of Maryland condemned his party’s nominee for state attorney general over the weekend for previously promoting a conspiracy theory about the Sept. 11 attacks. The governor criticized the G.O.P.’s direction two weeks after its voters chose far-right candidates for top state offices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Deshaun Watson’s Suspension Will Test the N.F.L.’s Support for Women
description: The N.F.L. must decide whether to uphold Watson’s six-game suspension or impose a more severe penalty. Its choice will speak volumes, writes our columnist.
content: Six games off. That’s the suspension. That’s it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Cora Engelbrecht
title: England Exults After Its Women’s Soccer Team Wins a Major Trophy
description: The dramatic 2-1 victory over Germany in the European Championship final touched off celebrations that have been more than 50 years in the waiting.
content: LONDON — For over 50 years, English soccer fans have hoped, prayed and sung that a major trophy would “come home.” Now it finally has. And they can hardly contain themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: U.S. will send another $550 million in arms to Ukraine.
description: The new materiel includes ammunition for 155-millimeter howitzers and for HIMARS rocket launchers, which have enabled Ukraine to destroy Russian command posts and ammunition depots.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House announced on Monday that the United States would send another $550 million in arms to Ukraine to help it fend off Russian invaders, increasing the total American investment in war fighting there to more than $8 billion since the invasion began in February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: How Hot and Humid Singapore Is Trying to Cool Itself Down
description: With the help of a mobile cart named “Smarty,” researchers are trying to tackle the challenge of urban heat through a program that the government says could be a model for other countries.
content: SINGAPORE — The temperature had reached 86 degrees and was climbing. Humidity measured in at 75 percent. Sunshine glinted off the tall buildings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Four Cheeses That Can’t Be Beat
description: These cheeses took top honors at the American Cheese Society’s annual competition.
content: To stock your cheese board it might pay to note this year’s top selections in the annual judging by the American Cheese Society. They were announced last week at the group’s conference in Portland, Ore. There are scores of categories for cheeses, butters and cultured dairy products, with winners in each. But only four were named Best in Show. In first place was Whitney, a Raclette-style cheese from Jasper Hill Farm in Greensboro Bend, Vt. Second place went to two cheeses: Flagsheep, a semihard blend of cow and sheep milks by Beecher’s Handmade Cheese in Seattle; and Bamboozle, a washed-rind blend of goat and cow milks from Rodeo Farm & Dairy in Allison Park, Pa. In third place was another Jasper Hill Farm cheese, Greensward, a soft-ripened washed rind beauty made in collaboration with Murray’s Cheese in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Can Inflation Reduction Save the Planet?
description: This bill just might catalyze a crucial energy transition.
content: After all the false starts and dashed hopes of the past two years, I’m reluctant to count my chickens before they’ve actually been signed in the Oval Office. Still, it appears that Democrats have finally agreed on another major piece of legislation, the Inflation Reduction Act. And if it does become law, it will be a very big deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Pelosi’s Planned Taiwan Visit Tests China
description: Also, efforts to fight urban heat in Singapore and deadly anti-U.N. protests in Congo.
content: The Chinese military has warned of its readiness to defend its claims over Taiwan ahead of an expected visit from Nancy Pelosi, the U.S. House speaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Under Pressure to Cut Russian Ties, Maestro Forms New Orchestra
description: Teodor Currentzis, who has been criticized for his association with a Russian bank, has enlisted European benefactors to finance his new group, Utopia.
content: The conductor Teodor Currentzis, who has faced scrutiny since the start of the war in Ukraine because of his ties to a state-owned bank in Russia, announced on Monday that he would form a new international ensemble with the support of donors outside Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: A Pelosi Trip to Taiwan Would Test China’s Appetite for Confrontation
description: Xi Jinping has long vowed to answer any challenge to China’s claim to Taiwan. But current economic and political forces may make him unlikely to court a crisis.
content: Soon after Beijing’s last big confrontation with Washington over Taiwan, Xi Jinping, then a rising official in a Chinese province that faces the disputed island, joined a reserve artillery division, and later had himself photographed in military greens, cap turned backward as he peered through the sights of an antiaircraft gun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: What the Floods Left Behind: A Devastated Kentucky Views the Damage
description: As search and rescue teams worked to find more victims, residents began surveying the wreckage.
content: Search and rescue operations continued on Monday in eastern Kentucky, where devastating floods, the product of extreme rainfall, swept through rural communities last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Bill Cosby to Seek a New Trial in Judy Huth Sex Assault Case
description: Ms. Huth was awarded $500,000 in damages in June by a California civil court jury that heard her describe how Mr. Cosby had sexually assaulted her in 1975 when she was 16.
content: Bill Cosby’s lawyers have announced they are seeking a new trial in a civil case in California where a jury in June found he sexually assaulted Judy Huth when she was 16.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: August 1, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, August 1, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Bad Bunny Reigns Again Before Beyoncé’s Chart Arrival
description: The Puerto Rican pop star logs a seventh week at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart; numbers for “Renaissance,” Beyoncé’s latest, arrive next week.
content: Before Beyoncé arrives with oomph on the charts, Bad Bunny is spending a seventh nonconsecutive week at No. 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Miller
title: Hello, World. It’s Been a While.
description: On the pleasures and pains of joining up with other people after a long, quiet time in the Covid doldrums.
content: I am traveling on a train, reading a book, glad to be alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams and Tania Ganguli
title: Why Pros Like Brittney Griner Choose Cannabis for Their Pain
description: Griner, the W.N.B.A. star detained in Russia on drug charges, is one of many athletes who have said cannabis helps with sports injuries. But it is banned by sports leagues and illegal in many places.
content: Shawn Kemp played most of his N.B.A. career before the league began testing players for marijuana use in 1999. So after playing in the bruising, physical games typical of the N.B.A. in the 1990s, he would smoke. He didn’t like taking pain-relief pills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim
title: Trump-Backed Conspiracy Theorist Vies to Take Over Arizona Elections
description: Mark Finchem, a full-throated MAGA warrior, is a leading contender to be Arizona’s next secretary of state. He has said he won’t concede if he loses.
content: PHOENIX — This spring, Mark Finchem traveled to Mar-a-Lago for the premiere of a documentary advancing the specious notion that the 2020 presidential election had been stolen from President Donald J. Trump by an army of leftists stuffing drop boxes with absentee ballots. As a state representative and candidate for secretary of state in Arizona, Mr. Finchem was a minnow among the assembled MAGA stars, the likes of Rudolph W. Giuliani and Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: In Races for Governor, Democrats See a Silver Lining
description: For Republicans, anemic fund-raising, missteps by Donald J. Trump and weak candidates could stand in the way of bigger statehouse gains in November.
content: WASHINGTON — Republican missteps, weak candidates and fund-raising woes are handing Democrats unexpected opportunities in races for governor this year, including in two states with departing Republican chief executives and in a number led by Democrats where G.O.P. contenders now face far longer odds than they had hoped.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Housing Costs Turn Into Crisis in Resort Town
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 1, 2022
content: “We live in a town of Wizard of Oz. People say one thing, and then behind a closed curtain they’re doing another.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greta Rybus
title: Cold-Plunging With Maine’s ‘Ice Mermaids’
description: A photographer in Maine has been documenting groups of women who submerge themselves in near-freezing water. Here’s what she’s seen.
content: When I met Ida Lennestål for a plunge on a cold January day, she was pulling an ax from her car and switching into warmer boots. A few minutes later, she lit a fire in a nearby sauna — a small building cobbled together from a former fish house and an old stove — before we walked the short slope down to a frozen pond near her home in Georgetown, Maine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas Martin and Alan Cowell
title: Killed at 71, Ayman al-Zawahri Led a Life of Secrecy and Violence
description: A radicalized Egyptian physician, he was regarded as the intellectual spine of Osama bin Laden’s terrorist organization, and ran it after Bin Laden was killed in 2011.
content: Ayman al-Zawahri, the Egyptian-born surgeon-turned-jihadist who assumed the leadership of Al Qaeda after the killing of Osama bin Laden and who died at 71 in a drone strike in Kabul, Afghanistan, over the weekend, according to U.S. officials, led a life steeped in secrecy, betrayal, conspiracy and violence, most murderously in the Sept. 11 attacks against the United States in 2001.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harvey Araton
title: Bill Russell’s Words Were Worth the Wait
description: In wit and wisdom, Russell left an impression with his gravelly voice. “It wasn’t like he tried to impress you with big words,” said one recipient of his advice.
content: Rare was the working person around N.B.A. arenas these past few decades who never had an encounter with the majestic Bill Russell. On occasion, mostly a special one, he was an intimidating presence walking tall and transcendent, in the manner of a man who had invented the game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurtis Lee
title: Who’s to Blame for a Factory Shutdown: A Company, or California?
description: The closing of a meatpacking plant near downtown Los Angeles has left its workers reeling and amplified questions about doing business in the state.
content: VERNON, Calif. — Teresa Robles begins her shift around dawn most days at a pork processing plant in an industrial corridor four miles south of downtown Los Angeles. She spends eight hours on her feet cutting tripe, a repetitive motion that has given her constant joint pain, but also a $17.85-an-hour income that supports her family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Death Toll in Kentucky Rises to 37, With More Flooding Expected
description: Rain was expected to douse parts of eastern Kentucky on Monday night, after dozens of people were killed in flash floods.
content: Heavy rain was expected to produce more flooding across already-saturated eastern Kentucky on Monday night, after flash floods in the area last week killed at least 37 people and left dozens missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: ‘Paradise Square’ Faces New Complaints Over Payments
description: The shuttered show is facing legal action from the actors, stage managers and designers who worked on the production.
content: A union representing the director and choreographers who worked on the recently closed Broadway musical “Paradise Square” is asking a federal court to enforce an arbitration award that was agreed upon in May, according to a lawsuit filed late last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: The Classical Music Event of the Summer Is in Salzburg’s Shadow
description: With surprising concerts performed at the highest level, the Ouverture Spirituelle is part of the Salzburg Festival but outshines it.
content: SALZBURG, Austria — Shostakovich’s “Babi Yar” Symphony, a celebration and condemnation of Russian life and cultural memory, was met at the Grosses Festspielhaus here on a recent evening with a standing ovation that lasted over five minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Ukraine wages a ‘deep war’ to degrade Russian forces as Moscow continues its scorched-earth campaign.
description: An attack on a train over the weekend was the latest in a series of strikes that have disrupted Russian logistical efforts and inflicted grave losses.
content: A Russian train carrying troops and equipment to reinforce positions in southern Ukraine was blown up by American-supplied precision missiles over the weekend, killing dozens of soldiers and destroying many rail cars, according to Ukrainian officials, who released satellite imagery of the strike site to support their claim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Ukraine Ships Grain at Last. It Will Take Far More to Slow Global Hunger.
description: The departure of a grain-filled vessel from Odesa was hailed as a victory against global hunger. But experts say the crisis is so big that no single advance can reverse it.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — In the Horn of Africa, villagers trek for days across dust-blown wastelands to escape drought-induced famine. In cities from Syria to Central America, families go to bed hungry. In Afghanistan, starving children stream into hospitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.7 Million Homes in California
description: An English country-style home in Carmel Valley, a 1923 farmhouse in Laurel Canyon and a three-bedroom retreat a few blocks from the beach in Oceanside.
content: This house is in the hills above Carmel Valley, a 10-minute drive from the quaint downtown that draws tourists with its wine-tasting rooms and upscale resorts. It is a five-minute drive from the hiking, riding and bike trails in Garland Ranch Regional Park and about 20 minutes from Carmel-by-the-Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: How the U.S. Let 20 Million Doses of Monkeypox Vaccine Expire
description: At the start of the monkeypox outbreak the U.S. stockpile contained just 2,400 doses of vaccine, a far cry from the more than 20 million it once held.
content: Less than a decade ago, the United States had some 20 million doses of a new smallpox vaccine — also effective against monkeypox — sitting in freezers in a national stockpile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Justice Dept. and Penguin Random House’s sparring over merger has begun.
description: The trial to decide whether the publishing giant may buy Simon & Schuster is a test of the Biden administration’s push to expand antitrust enforcement.
content: A federal judge on Monday began a trial that will decide whether Penguin Random House is allowed to buy Simon & Schuster, a case that could significantly affect the book publishing industry and that will test the Biden administration’s efforts to expand antitrust enforcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: One Woman’s Life in Subsidized Housing, and Her Campaign to Fix It
description: At the Holmes Towers on the Upper East Side, La Keesha Taylor has formed a coalition to keep the elevators running, the heat working and the rodents at bay.
content: Most mornings, La Keesha Taylor spends a few minutes in bed with her eyes open after she wakes up, sizing up the day ahead of her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Michael Levenson
title: ‘One miscalculation away from nuclear annihilation’: The U.N. chief issues a grim warning, citing war.
description: The conflict in Ukraine and tensions over North Korea and Iran have lifted the threat of nuclear disaster to a level not seen since the Cold War.
content: The secretary general of the United Nations warned on Monday that humanity was “just one misunderstanding, one miscalculation away from nuclear annihilation,” citing the war in Ukraine among the conflicts driving the risk to a level not seen since the height of the Cold War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim and Ken Belson
title: Here Are the Longest N.F.L. Player Suspensions
description: Deshaun Watson’s six-game suspension, imposed by a retired federal judge, was the first player conduct penalty reached by the N.F.L.’s new hearing process.
content: Quarterback Deshaun Watson was suspended Monday for six games for violating the N.F.L.’s personal conduct policy and was not fined, concluding the league’s 15-month investigation into sexual misconduct claims made against him by more than two dozen women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: This Wine Bag Is Ready for the Picnic
description: Wine Enthusiast’s new tote is designed to carry wine bottles, as well as bread and cheese.
content: Unlike many bags designed for carrying wine, the new canvas tote from Wine Enthusiast also has food in mind. Its new farmers’ market bag is well provisioned with pockets to hold jars, baguettes, even bunches of herbs and flowers, and wine bottles to be sure. It has a removable inner insulated cooler pouch for perishables like cheeses and charcuterie. There’s a leather shoulder strap in addition to carrying handles. It measures 11 inches square and is 13 inches high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: The Rise of the Anti-Vaccine Voter
description: And Biden’s “Paxlovid rebound.”
content: A new, potentially destabilizing political movement has been born out of the pandemic: parents who joined the anti-vaccine and anti-mask cause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Who Is Vladimir Putin?
description: Philip Short’s “Putin” is an impressive biography but one that necessarily lacks the final chapters of the story.
content: PUTIN, by Philip Short
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Legal Onslaught Facing Credit Card Companies
description: Visa faces questions about whether it enabled a porn site to profit from images of child sexual abuse, and both Mastercard and Visa face a new antitrust suit from Disney.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: First Capitol Rioter to Face Trial Gets 7 Years, Longest Sentence So Far
description: Guy Wesley Reffitt was convicted in March on five counts in a case viewed as a test for the Justice Department.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Monday sentenced Guy Wesley Reffitt, the first defendant to go on trial in the Justice Department’s sprawling criminal inquiry into the Jan. 6 attack, to more than seven years in prison, the longest sentence to date in a case stemming from the Capitol riot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: U.S. Warns China Not to Turn Pelosi’s Expected Trip to Taiwan Into a ‘Crisis’
description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi, a longtime China hawk, has not confirmed that she plans to visit Taiwan, but all indications suggest that she will make a stop on the self-governing island without prior announcement.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States warned China on Monday not to respond to an expected trip to Taiwan by Speaker Nancy Pelosi with military provocations even as American officials sought to reassure Beijing that such a visit would not be the first of its kind nor represent any change in policy toward the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Smart Advice From an Upstate Cook
description: “To the Last Bite,” by the Catskills cookbook author Alexis deBoschnek, delivers alluring recipes that help solve cooking quandaries.
content: The recipe developer Alexis deBoschnek’s first cookbook, “To the Last Bite: Recipes and Ideas for Making the Most of Your Ingredients,” a bright volume of alluring recipes, is true to its title. It’s a waste-not cookbook that suggests sautéing the dark green tops of leeks in butter for a frittata and, recognizing “there’s always leftover buttermilk,” gives additional uses beyond a ricotta recipe. Among the finds in its pages are chocolate chip cookies made with only whole wheat flour, seared pork on a bed of red grapes and onions, roasted strawberries for shortcakes and a summer tomato galette. Ms. deBoschnek grew up on a farm in the western Catskills where she gardened with her mother, Heleen Heyning, and now lives nearby in Delhi, N.Y., all of which is reflected in the text and recipes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: Review: ‘M. Butterfly’ Metamorphoses Again, as an Opera
description: David Henry Hwang has returned to his Tony-winning play with a libretto for Huang Ruo’s new work. But can its story change with the times?
content: SANTA FE, N.M. — “M. Butterfly” has been a Broadway hit, a watershed in Asian American representation, a film, and recently a revised version of the original play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: J. Lo and Liz Cheney and Us
description: I no longer believe that a woman’s decision to change her name signifies anything except what feels right to her.
content: NASHVILLE — The long-delayed nuptials of Jennifer Lopez and Ben Affleck has generated a predictable flurry of commentary about everything from the bride’s trousseau to her decision to take the groom’s last name. The dresses are pretty, sure, but it’s the name I can’t stop thinking about. What does a choice like that, by one of the most recognizable and influential women in the country, say about our cultural moment? A moment when coordinated attacks on women’s privacy and autonomy extend across the red-state legislatures all the way to the United States Supreme Court?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller, Josh Katz, Francesca Paris and Aatish Bhatia
title: Vast New Study Shows a Key to Reducing Poverty: More Friendships Between Rich and Poor
description: An analysis of 21 billion Facebook friendships, covering 84 percent of U.S. adults aged 25 to 44, puts cross-class relationships at the heart of income mobility.

title: Read the Judge’s Decision Suspending Deshaun Watson
description: Sue L. Robinson, a retired federal judge, ruled that Deshaun Watson be suspended for six games for violating the N.F.L.’s personal conduct policy. Watson has been accused by more than two dozen women of sexual misconduct.

title: What You Get for $2.7 Million in California
description: An English country-style home in Carmel Valley, a 1923 farmhouse in Los Angeles and a three-bedroom retreat a few blocks from the beach in Oceanside.
content: An English country-style home in Carmel Valley, a 1923 farmhouse in Los Angeles and a three-bedroom retreat a few blocks from the beach in Oceanside.

author: By The New York Times
title: Pelosi Has Right to Visit Taiwan, White House Says
description: John F. Kirby, a National Security Council spokesman, warned China against military provocations over an expected trip to Taiwan by Speaker Nancy Pelosi, noting that other lawmakers have visited before.
content: John F. Kirby, a National Security Council spokesman, warned China against military provocations over an expected trip to Taiwan by Speaker Nancy Pelosi, noting that other lawmakers have visited before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By United Nations
title: Video Shows Ship Loaded With Grain Leaving Ukraine Port
description: A ship loaded with Ukrainian grain left the Port of Odesa for the first time since Russia’s invasion, following an international deal aimed at lowering global food prices.
content: A ship loaded with Ukrainian grain left the Port of Odesa for the first time since Russia’s invasion, following an international deal aimed at lowering global food prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Anthony for The New York Times and Reuters
title: Kentucky Floods Leave Behind Devastation
description: Rescue crews worked to restore power and water and to recover bodies after floods ravaged southeastern Kentucky. More than three dozen people were confirmed dead, and the toll was expected to climb.
content: Rescue crews worked to restore power and water and to recover bodies after floods ravaged southeastern Kentucky. More than three dozen people were confirmed dead, and the toll was expected to climb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: United States Will Send Ukraine Another $550 Million in Military Aid
description: The latest arms package to Ukraine will increase the total American investment in war fighting to more than $8 billion since Russia’s invasion began.
content: The latest arms package to Ukraine will increase the total American investment in war fighting to more than $8 billion since Russia’s invasion began.
source.name: The New York Times

title: LIV Golf, Trump and the Saudi Connection
description: Political dimensions of the LIV event at a Trump golf course. Also: Norman Lear’s gift; women’s health; guns in Texas schools; cellphones on the subway.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Fish with citrus and chiles is the light, summery dinner that a late-July evening demands.
content: Good morning. Rabbit rabbit. Ligaya Mishan took to the pages of The New York Times Magazine this weekend to praise the inventive, improvisatory cooking of her husband. The couple are cooks as they are musicians — they both trained as pianists. But where Ligaya plays notes? Her husband composes them.
source.name: The New York Times
